I may be over-interpreting the CPPN process, but it stimulated a few
ideas.=
  I work in the field of Computational Chemistry and my in my
day to day op=
erations I deal with drug-like chemical compounds.  The
3D shape of a chemi=
cal is a principle determining factor of its
activity.  On top of 3D shape,=
 you have different functional groups
that impart different properties.  Fo=
r example, let's say the shape is
just right to bind to a particular enzyme=
 (and prevent it from running
amok) but you need an oxygen atom at a partic=
ular location, or a
nitrogen, or any atom with a hydrogen attached, etc.

T=
here are two ways to get to this type of information.  First is
having a la=
rge collection of chemicals with a known endpoint.  For
this I usually appl=
y the standard pattern recognition tools.  Another
more difficult approach =
is when you don't have much data for
chemicals, but you know the 3D structu=
re of the enzyme and where you
want your chemical to bind.  I'm wondering i=
f there is an application
for CPPNs here.  Can the CPPN capture the shape o=
f the site along with
the essential properties based on the protein itself =
and then be used
to assess different chemical compounds that have not yet b=
een tested -
try to predict their activities.

Any thoughts??

-Kirk



---=
 In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> Kirk,=
 what is your idea for applying CPPNs to pattern recognition?  I
> am not s=
ure I followed exactly how the CPPN would be connected to the
> neural netw=
ork?
> 
> As Peter mentioned, we have used the idea of CPPNs to represent
>=
 connectivity patterns rather than the spatial patterns you saw in the
> CP=
PN paper.  These connectivity patterns can then be interpreted of
> neural =
network connectivity patterns, which means you can evolve
> neural networks=
 with regularities in their connectivities.  There are
> currently four pap=
ers on this approach to evolving ANNs with CPPNs,
> which is called HyperNE=
AT.  Those papers are available from my homepage
> 
> http://www.cs.ucf.edu=
/~kstanley/
> 
> or from EPlex publications:
> 
> http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/p=
ublications.html
> 
> The particular papers are:
> 
> -A Novel Generative E=
ncoding for Exploiting Neural Network Sensor and 
> Output Geometry
> 
> -G=
enerating Large-Scale Neural Networks Through Discovering Geometric
> Regul=
arities 
> 
> -A Case Study on the Critical Role of Geometric Regularity in=
 Machine
> Learning
> 
> -Generative Encoding for Multiagent Learning 
> 
>=
 A longer journal paper on HyperNEAT is also forthcoming in Artificial
> Li=
fe journal.
> 
> By the way, you can also interactively evolve your own CPP=
Ns images
> online at http://picbreeder.org
> 
> Because spatial patterns a=
nd connectivity patterns can represent just
> about anything, there are oth=
er potential applications of CPPNs beyond
> representing ANNs, but currentl=
y there is no publication of such an
> application that I know of.  But it =
would be interesting to see more
> work in that direction.
> 
> ken 
> 
> 
=
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" <petar_chervenski@>
> wro=
te:
> >
> > HyperNEAT uses CPPNs to build the neural network phenotypes (an=
d

e 
> > papers on HyperNEAT. It should be interesting to you, though it is
j=
ust 
> > one of all possible applications. 
> > 
> > Peter

> > --- In =
neat@yahoogroups.com, "newtwist2000" <rkdelisle@> wrote:
> > >
> > > I've j=
ust read through the paper Compositional Pattern Producing
> > > Networks: =
A Novel Abstraction of Development - very interesting
stuff.
> > >  
> > > =
Are there additional papers that extend on this?  Currently what I'm
> > > =
seeing is based on visual representations, but are there papers
where
> > >=
 this has been extended to pattern recognition or other fields?  My
> > > t=
hought is that if a CPPN can capture important spatial details that
> > > c=
an then be evaluated by a standard NN, can the two improve on
pattern
> > >=
 recognition tasks that have a relative spatial component -
> > > topologic=
al, geometric, higher dimensions...
> > > 
> > > -Kirk
> > >
